docs.snippet: LONDON, June 12. -- Like the conference itself, the broadcast of the King's opening address was the biggest ever organized, hundreds of thousands of kilowatts being expended throughout the world in conveying the speech to millions of listeners.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 12. -- Like the conference itself, the broadcast of the King's opening address was the biggest ever organized, hundreds of thousands of kilowatts being expended throughout the world in conveying the speech to millions of listeners.

headline.main: RECORD BROADCAST MADE BY THE KING; Address at Opening of London Conference Reaches All Parts of the World. 100 STATIONS USED HERE Speech Is Recorded for Phono- graph Reproduction for Austra- lians When They Awakened.

docs.snippet: LONDON, June 13 -- The World Economic Conference got down to work today. King George's crimson upholstered chair had vanished from the platform which was occupied now only by the chairman and his aides and the conference began to clear off the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 13 -- The World Economic Conference got down to work today. King George's crimson upholstered chair had vanished from the platform which was occupied now only by the chairman and his aides and the conference began to clear off the preliminary speeches that the delegates must deliver before actual proposals can be taken up.
docs.abstract: s for Italy at World Economic Conf

headline.main: DEBTS AGAIN THRUST INTO LONDON PARLEY; Jung Demands Completion of Lausanne Accord -- Smuts Criticizes Our Delay. HULL POSTPONES SPEECH Lacking Time to Revise It, He Puts It Off Till Today -- 15 Nations for Tariff Truce. DEBTS AGAIN ENTER ECONOMIC PARLEY

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LONDON, June 13 -- The speeches at today's session of the World Economic Conference adhered for the most part to broad principles, to which virtually everybody subscribed, at least in the abstract. The speakers vied with each other in praising Prime...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 13 -- The speeches at today's session of the World Economic Conference adhered for the most part to broad principles, to which virtually everybody subscribed, at least in the abstract. The speakers vied with each other in praising Prime Minister MacDonald's denunciation of economic nationalism.

headline.main: END OF NATIONALISM IS URGED AT LONDON; Leaders in Conference Back MacDonald's Denunciation of Economic Trend. POLITICAL ISSUES DEBATED Germany Sees Problems Graver Than Trade Questions, but Smuts Would Bar Them.

byline.original: By HAROLD CALLENDER.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Our exports to a dozen leading markets increased, but our imports in the first quarter of 1933 were 31 per cent lower in value than for the first quarter of 1932, and 66 per cent under the 1928-1932 average, according to the...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Our exports to a dozen leading markets increased, but our imports in the first quarter of 1933 were 31 per cent lower in value than for the first quarter of 1932, and 66 per cent under the 1928-1932 average, according to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

headline.main: OUR EXPORTS RISE TO 12 BIG MARKETS; Most of Them in Latin America, Chamber Report on First Quarter of Year Shows. IMPORTS STILL LAGGING Value 31% Under Period in 1932, but 38 Out of 90 Items Increase In Quantity.

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LONDON, June 20 -- Approval was given today by the subcommittee on monetary rehabilitation at the World Economic Conference to the American advocacy of the earliest practicable stabilization of moneys and of the readoption of the gold standard as an...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 20 -- Approval was given today by the subcommittee on monetary rehabilitation at the World Economic Conference to the American advocacy of the earliest practicable stabilization of moneys and of the readoption of the gold standard as an international measure of exchange values.
docs.abstract: Subcom approves clauses of Pittman proposal dealing with stabilization and readoption of gold standard; clauses recommending that central banks hold 20% of reserves in silver and that legal cover be reduced referred to subcom; silver proposal debated

headline.main: OUR VIEW ON GOLD GETS WIDE BACKING; Readoption of the Metal as a General Standard Is Urged by London Committee. REDUCED COVER FAVORED Only Uruguay Expresses Fear of Plan -- Silver Question Is Sent to Subcommittee.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 30. -- May exports from the United States surpassed the value of those for April in the case of twenty-three of' the forty principal foreign markets, the Commerce Department announced today. The total value was $114,243,398 or about...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30. -- May exports from the United States surpassed the value of those for April in the case of twenty-three of' the forty principal foreign markets, the Commerce Department announced today. The total value was $114,243,398 or about $9,000,000 larger than the preceding month.
docs.abstract: Rept for May by Dept of Commerce

headline.main: MAY EXPORTS ROSE TO 23 BIG MARKETS; Our Sales to Three of Seven of Grand Divisions Also Increased Over April. GAIN TO EUROPE $4,000,000 Imports for Month From All of Grand Divisions and From 30 Countries Were Larger.

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: The net result of the few transactions, reported by the Federal Reserve, of changes in gold holdings in June was a small gain for the United States. It amounted to $277,000 and followed a gain of $710,200 in May. Imports of the metal from Latin...
docs.lead_paragraph: The net result of the few transactions, reported by the Federal Reserve, of changes in gold holdings in June was a small gain for the United States. It amounted to $277,000 and followed a gain of $710,200 in May. Imports of the metal from Latin America accounted for the addition.
docs.abstract: Rept for June on imports and exports; figures for 1st 6 mos of year on movements through ports of San Francisco and N Y

headline.main: GOLD HOLDINGS UP $277,000 IN MONTH; Imports From Latin America Account for Increase in the United States. DECREASE IN EARMARKINGS Net Loss in Nation's Stock in First Half of This Year Put at $165,660,000.
